items.title: Add $cd watchman-vYYYY.MM.DD.00-linux before sudo $cp bin/* /usr/local/bin
items.body:
Just a suggestion to add
`$cd watchman-vYYYY.MM.DD.00-linux`
before
`$cp bin/* /usr/local/bin`
in the instructions for Binary downloads Linux and MacOS section.
It will help someone simple copy-pasting the commands to not make the mistake.

Please add the command `$cd watchman-vYYYY.MM.DD.00-linux` at the place indicated by the blue `arrow.`
![watchman_new_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43148850/89985616-fca47f00-dc98-11ea-9265-03edc32896a5.png)


This is just a suggestion from a junior developer.
Please be gentle if it is a stupid suggestion.
I respect and admire developers at Facebook.

Hello there!

I appreciate the project. It is well documented. However, the readme could be made better by adding some basic installation and usage info. What do you think?

items.title: watchman refuses to use inotify on FUSE filesystems
items.body:
Unfortunately, after upgrading watchman to the latest version (v2020.07.13.00) from 4.9.0 it started failing to run.
I have a simple docker container running under the Docker for Mac application. It shares a volume with the host machine (mounted to the `/code` path) and running `watchman watch /code` fails with the following error:
```
# watchman watch /code
{
    "version": "20200712.162157.0",
    "error": "RootResolveError: unable to resolve root /code: inotify: cannot watch FUSE file systems with inotify. "
}
```

Is it possible to resolve, or such installation isn't supported by watchman?

items.title: Unless `suffix` is included in a `query`, `node_modules` are ignored
items.body:
## Includes `node_modules`

```diff
watchman -j <<-EOT
["query", ".", {
+ "suffix": "js",
  "expression": [
    "allof",
    ["type", "f"],
    ["anyof", ["suffix", "js"]]
  ],
  "fields": ["name", "exists",  "mtime_ms",  "size",  "content.sha1hex"],
  "glob": ["**/*.js"]
  }]
EOT
```

## Doesn't include `node_modules`

```diff
watchman -j <<-EOT
["query", ".", {
- "suffix": "js",
  "expression": [
    "allof",
    ["type", "f"],
    ["anyof", ["suffix", "js"]]
  ],
  "fields": ["name", "exists",  "mtime_ms",  "size",  "content.sha1hex"],
  "glob": ["**/*.js"]
  }]
EOT
```

items.title: Watchman CLI and `fb-watchman` with the same query are giving different results
items.body:
I am using `metro` which uses `jest-haste-map` which uses `fb-watchman` to send commands using BSER.

I've tried the same command in the CLI and in `metro` and in `metro` I get many fewer results and no `node_modules` dependencies.

What could be causing this? Does watchman avoid `node_modules` dirs?

items.title: Feature request: Declarative configuration of triggers via config file
items.body: I would like to be able to declaratively specify watchman triggers in the watchman config file, for triggers that I wish to be active for the lifetime of the watchman service (example: watching some directory and running a script for each torrent file added to it, to automate downloading linux distros). Currently, there is no way to do so, but since both the watchman config file and the watchman state file are stored as json, it should be fairly simple to include a config file field such as `additional_triggers` that uses the same trigger format as in the state file to allow for declarative configuration of triggers.

items.title: Can watchman watch things on AWS EFS?
items.body:
Hey!

I mounted an AWS EFS (Elastic File System) to an EC2 instance. I realized that I can't use inotifywait to watch for changes on the efs... this is beacuse inotify works by hooking into the kernels 'write' code. As remote filesystems like EFS have the ability for other things to write to them, without the kernel being aware of it, inotify explicitly does not work for them.

Would watchman work on EFS or does it use some of the kernel features like inotify wait?

items.title: Migrate Website to Docusaurus 2 Alpha
items.body:
Hi there! The Docusaurus team is currently developing Docusaurus 2 and are almost done with an MVP that doesn't include translations and versioning features, which means there's feature parity with your website's current usage of Docusaurus.

Docusaurus 2 brings about many improvements:

- Client-side rendering with prerendering (site renders without JavaScript!)

items.title: Windows: handle remains open after `watch-del` command
items.body:
I'm using Git's fsmonitor tool with Watchman to speed up performance when there are many files. However, after using the repo, I'm unable to delete it without closing the watchman process (on Windows). There must be an open handle somewhere still.

I'm using the `watch-del` command to remove the watch, but the handle still is not closed.

```
$ watchman watch-list
{
    "version": "4.9.4",
    "roots": [
        "C:/_git/ForTests/src"
    ]
}

$ rm -rf ForTests
rm: cannot remove 'ForTests/src': Device or resource busy

$ watchman watch-del "C:/_git/ForTests/src"

$ watchman watch-list
{
    "version": "4.9.4",
    "roots": []
}

$ rm -rf ForTests
rm: cannot remove 'ForTests/src': Device or resource busy

$ handle.exe | grep -B 1 ForTests
cmd.exe pid: 24192 DESKTOP-LE3SIE3\stole
   40: File  (RW-)   C:\_git\ForTests\src
--
watchman.exe pid: 22960 DESKTOP-LE3SIE3\stole
   44: File  (RW-)   C:\_git\ForTests\src
```

(The "cmd.exe" process reported by `handle.exe` is the background runner that is running `watchman.exe` as a child.)

I'm struggling to read the code and connect the dots (especially because I've failed to build it locally). I see that `FileDescriptor` has a destructor that will clear the handle, and that should be part of the destructor for `WinDirHandle` (which extends `watchman_dir_handle`). What I don't see is any connection between the code in `watchlist.cpp` and those types.

If it helps, it is important to note that a query must be asked of `watchman` in order to trigger this failure. This Python test _may_ demonstrate the bug:

```
@WatchmanTestCase.expand_matrix
class TestHandles(WatchmanTestCase.WatchmanTestCase):
    def checkOSApplicability(self):
        if sys.platform != "win32":
            self.skipTest("N/A unless Windows")

    def test_handles(self):

        root = self.mkdtemp()
        self.watchmanCommand("watch", root)
        self.touchRelative(root, "file")
        self.watchmanCommand("watch-del", root)
        os.rmdir(root)
        self.assertFalse(os.path.isdir("root"))
```

I'm happy to commit time to fix this issue, but I'll need a little guidance for where to look. My initial inspection has led me in circles so I figured I would write this issue while everything is fresh.

items.title: Error: Watchman error: too many pending cache jobs
items.body:
# Problem

When I create my react-native bundle - the watchman crawl initially fails with "`too many pending cache jobs`", which seems to slow down the bundling process:

```
$ react-native start --reset-cache
```

> Loading dependency graph...jest-haste-map: Watchman crawl failed. Retrying once with node crawler.

> Usually this happens when watchman isn't running. Create an empty `.watchmanconfig` file in your project's root folder or initialize a git or hg repository in your project.

> Error: Watchman error: too many pending cache jobs. Make sure watchman is running for this project. See https://facebook.github.io/watchman/docs/troubleshooting.html

Also, these may be related:

 * I can get rid of the error by excluding `node_modules` from the watch config
 * Without the error, and the bundler starts in **20 seconds**
 * With the error, the craw takes 4 seconds, but the bundler starts in **4 minutes**

# Background

## Pre-bundle scripts

I run these before the bundler, to attempt to get more stability:

```sh
watchman watch-del-all
watchman shutdown-server
sudo sysctl -w kern.maxfiles=5242880
sudo sysctl -w kern.maxfilesperproc=524288
```

## Watchman config file

I set my `.watchconfig` file to be extra permissable:

```json
{
  "ignore_dirs": [],
  "fsevents_latency": 0.5,
  "fsevents_try_resync": true
}
```

## Watchman log

The crawl **does complete**, within a few seconds according to the full log

```sh
$ tail -f /usr/local/var/run/watchman/coolman-state/log
```



items.title: xattr support
items.body:
Hello. I would like to be able to detect when extended attributes on my files change (xattr). At the moment I'd be happy to know when any xattrs change in a given fs tree. More advanced implementations might let me match on which attribute, or further match by attribute's value, but for now, I'd just like to be made aware of which files have xattr() changes happening.

I'm not sure if Linux &c currently have a normative way to watch for xattr changes. If not, I'd suggest the problem be decoupled some: a eBPF tracing program could be written & applied to processes to watch for setxattr syscalls & to pick out the patch & that watchman could look at that feed & try to generate events where it finds matching project paths.

items.title: wildmatch glob syntax undocumented
items.body:
If someone will explain to me what glob syntaxes are supported, I will open a PR to update the docs.

As far as I can tell only `**` and `*` are supported. Many people are used to working with glob implementations which support more syntaxes than this, so offering clarity on what is supported would be great. In general I think it's just good practice to always define possible syntaxes.

items.title: Different behavior watching directory under symlink socket vs CLI
items.body:
Hello —

With a project directory like:
```
/code/lives/at/projectDir
```

and a symlink from

```
/path/to/symlinkToCodeDir --> /code/lives/at
```

watching then calling `clock` on `/path/to/symlinkToCodeDir/projectDir` behaves inconsistently between the CLI or sending commands to the watchman socket.

- I'm running Mac OS 10.14.4.

- For both, a `watch-project /path/to/symlinkToCodeDir/projectDir` succeeds
- From the command line, `clock /path/to/symlinkToCodeDir/projectDir` works, but sending the same thing to the watchman socket fails with an error like:
```
unable to resolve root /path/to/symlinkToCodeDir/projectDir: unable to lstat "/path/to/symlinkToCodeDir/projectDir" open: /path/to/symlinkToCodeDir: Too many levels of symbolic links
```

From some initial investigation, this is failing at https://github.com/facebook/watchman/blob/master/FileDescriptor.cpp#L663, because the parent of the root is a symlink, but in the open options used `followSymlinks` is zero, so we set `O_NOFOLLOW` at https://github.com/facebook/watchman/blob/master/FileDescriptor.cpp#L217 . I experimented with setting `followSymlinks` to true in the `queryFileInfo` options, but then, while the `open` succeeded, we later failed in a comparison of the passed path to the canonicalized one (they are indeed different).

It feels like the symlink handling logic in here is pretty complicated, so rather than continuing trying to debug I figured I would open an issue and see if this was something you all could help with.


This particular directory / symlink setup did work on watchman 4.7

items.title: can watchman-make rerun scripts that do not exit?
items.body:
watchman-make is not restarting my server/infinate loop script.

```watchman-make -p 'swapWindowFocusListener' --run 'server_script'```
then I tried:
```watchman-make -p 'swapWindowFocusListener' --run 'pkill -f "^python3 path/to/server_script$"; server_script'```

server_script
``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# blocking/non-exiting server code

```

while trying to take a look at `watchman-make`s python code installed on my system, I discovered `watchman-wait` and made a little bash script that reruns scripts that don't exit. 

``` bash
#!/bin/bash
# watch and on save rerun scripts that dont exit.
# first argument ($1) is a commandline only of this form:
# runner script_path [args], e.g python|node path/to/script.py|.js --h
cmdln="$1" #echo ${cmdln}
arr=($cmdln)
length=${#arr[@]} #echo "length $length"
if (( $length >= 2 )); then
    path="${arr[1]}" #echo "path $path"
    while true; do
        $cmdln &
        forkedPid=$!
        watchman-wait "$path"
        if [[ "$?" -ne "0" ]]; then
            echo "watchman exit status: $?.. not 0, exiting.."
            kill $forkedPid
            exit 1
        fi
        kill $forkedPid
    done
fi
```

items.title: Downloading latest windows builds gives non-functional watchman
items.body:
The link to download the latest watchman build leads users to download builds which are failing on Appveyor. This leads them to raise issues like #681 and #675. Expecting them to download dlls provided by other well meaning peers is not secure, as seen here: https://github.com/facebook/watchman/issues/627#issuecomment-464461216.

### The workaround
The trick is to download a build from Appveyor which is **passing**. So, head to the source of the Windows builds: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/wez/watchman/history, and keep scrolling down and click *Show More* until you see a build which is passing (green border):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/760112/53321470-95f1a100-38fe-11e9-9547-4a3ac6df0e2d.png)

Click on the commit message to go to that build, then click the "Artifacts" link to view the artifacts page:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/760112/53321516-be799b00-38fe-11e9-8488-22bded58b7d3.png)

where you can download the `watchman.zip` file:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/760112/53321528-c76a6c80-38fe-11e9-9b49-ce24993555c2.png)

Extract **all** the useful contents (*.exe, *.dll) and put them somewhere in your path. I put them in a folder called `C:\bin\misc`. Then open a new cmd or powershell, and run `watchman version`. It should work.

items.title: Error while loading shared libraries: double-conversion.dll:
items.body:
I am getting errors while running watchman on Windows 7:

`watchman --version`
`C:/Program Files/watchman/watchman.exe: error while loading shared libraries: double-conversion.dll: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory`

items.title: Cannot run watchman.exe
items.body:
I was able to download the watchman zip for windows just fine, but when I try to run the .exe files, I get a couple of popup windows that give me these errors:

The code execution cannot proceed because glog.dll was not found. Reinstalling the program may fix this problem.

The code execution cannot proceed because boost_context-vc141-mt-x64-1_67.dll was not found. Reinstalling the program may fix this problem.

The code execution cannot proceed because boost_thread-vc141-mt-x64-1_67.dll was not found. Reinstalling the program may fix this problem.

The code execution cannot proceed because double-conversion.dll was not found. Reinstalling the program may fix this problem.

To the best of my knowledge, I did not previously own these files and delete them. I tried reinstalling the program, but I run into the same issue. Is there a way around this?

items.title: unable to talk to your watchman ...
items.body:
OS: IOS Mojave
watchman: v4.9.0

in the last day or so, starting my react-native environment, long hang followed by watchman error:
```
[cli] unable to talk to your watchman on /opt/local/var/run/watchman/axian-state/sock! (No such file or directory)
```
which is absolutely true, there is no `sock!` at that location. Have no idea why it's suddenly looking for it?

items.title: New Release?
items.body:
Hey there! Thanks as always for the great work on Watchman.

It seems that v4.9 was released well over a year ago (in Aug of 2017). There's been a ton of work here since -- any chance we could get a new release?

Thanks!
-Adam

items.title: Watching .git/refs/** at runtime?
items.body:
I'm developing a tool that can be switched between watching a working tree and just watching for new commits to refs in a git repo.

I've run into what seems like a hurdle that `ignore_vcs` can't be changed at runtime. Based on the runtime config/flags to my tool, I either want to watch the working tree with `ignore_vcs`=`.git` in effect or I want to only watch `.git/HEAD` and `.git/refs/**`

Is there any way to change `ignore_vcs` in the context of `watch-project` or `subscribe`? It seems like this option could only be changed by the user outside of using my tool, and there's no way my tool could switch modes without the user toggling watchman config?

items.title: Shutdown Server Issue
items.body: Is it true that if a user accidentally watched his/her home directory, he/she will not be able to (a) shutdown the server (b) unwatch it?

items.title: Provide a Debian package as part of releases?
items.body: This would make installation much easier on services such as Travis CI. This is already done by Buck (for example https://github.com/facebook/buck/releases/tag/v2018.10.29.01)

items.title: Installing Watchman on macOS Mojave
items.body:
I was trying to install Watchman on macOS Mojave and got this error:

items.title: Command line option to skip tests
items.body:
```
./configure --disable-opt --without-python
```

`make` still compiles the tests for the python test suite. It is not desirable when building watchman inside a Docker container.

items.title: Crawling .leading-dot directories
items.body:
Does my query need something special to tell Watchman to crawl directories whose names begin with a leading period?

The following query does *not* seem to be doing so:
```json
{
  "expression": [
    "allof",
    [ "anyof",
      [ "dirname", "packages/react" ],
      [ "dirname", "packages/schedule" ],
      [ "dirname", "packages" ]
    ],
    [ "anyof",
      [ "allof",
        [ "type", "f" ],
        [ "not",
          [ "anyof",
            [ "match", "**/__tests__/**", "wholename" ],
            [ "match", "**/__fixtures__/**", "wholename" ],
            [ "match", "**/__mocks__/**", "wholename" ]
          ]
        ],
        [ "anyof",
          [ "suffix", "js" ],
          [ "suffix", "json" ],
          [ "suffix", "ts" ],
          [ "suffix", "tsx" ]
        ]
      ],
      [ "allof",
        [ "type", "l" ],
        [ "anyof",
          [
            "match", "**/node_modules/*", "wholename",
            { "includedotfiles": true }
          ],
          [
            "match", "**/node_modules/@*/*", "wholename",
            { "includedotfiles": true }
          ]
        ]
      ]
    ]
  ],
  "fields": [
    "name",
    "type",
    "exists",
    "mtime_ms"
  ],
  "glob": [
    "packages/react/**/node_modules/*",
    "packages/react/**/node_modules/@*/*",
    "packages/react/**/*.js",
    "packages/react/**/*.json",
    "packages/react/**/*.ts",
    "packages/react/**/*.tsx",
    "packages/schedule/**/node_modules/*",
    "packages/schedule/**/node_modules/@*/*",
    "packages/schedule/**/*.js",
    "packages/schedule/**/*.json",
    "packages/schedule/**/*.ts",
    "packages/schedule/**/*.tsx",
    "packages/**/node_modules/*",
    "packages/**/node_modules/@*/*",
    "packages/**/*.js",
    "packages/**/*.json",
    "packages/**/*.ts",
    "packages/**/*.tsx"
  ]
}
```

items.title: watchman-make not working on python3
items.body:
Hello! According to your docs pywatchman now supports python3. However I'm running into a python 2/3 compat issue.

```
$ watchman-make -p '**/*.py' -t unittest
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/schrockn/code/venvs/clarify/bin/watchman-make", line 168, in <module>
    args = parser.parse_args()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.6.4_3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/argparse.py", line 1730, in parse_args
    args, argv = self.parse_known_args(args, namespace)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.6.4_3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/argparse.py", line 1762, in parse_known_args
    namespace, args = self._parse_known_args(args, namespace)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.6.4_3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/argparse.py", line 1968, in _parse_known_args
    start_index = consume_optional(start_index)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.6.4_3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/argparse.py", line 1908, in consume_optional
    take_action(action, args, option_string)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/3.6.4_3/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/argparse.py", line 1836, in take_action
    action(self, namespace, argument_values, option_string)
  File "/Users/schrockn/code/venvs/clarify/bin/watchman-make", line 103, in __call__
    if isinstance(values, basestring):
NameError: name 'basestring' is not defined
```

Watchman version 4.9.0

```
$ watchman --version
4.9.0
```

Python version 3.6.4

```
$ python3 --version
Python 3.6.4
```

pywatchman 1.4.1 (from pip list)

```
pywatchman          1.4.1
```

Thanks again for open sourcing this awesome project.
